awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Applicability Limits of Aqueous pKa Values for Bulk and Surface Nanoparticle Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Chemistry Division's Environmental Chemical Sciences Program. The collaborative study involves Professors Kelley Barsanti and Bryan Wong at the University of California, Riverside, and Prof. James Smith at the University of California, Irvine. Together with their graduate and undergraduate students, they investigate the acidity of atmospheric aerosols (very fine droplets in the atmosphere). Several key processes that cause small particles to form and grow in the atmosphere are controlled by the acidity of the surface and interior of aerosol particles. The formation and growth of these small particles in the atmosphere have implications for their effects on health as well as their potential to directly and indirectly impact climate. Atmospheric aerosols are particles that are often smaller than 100 nanometers in diameter. Typical descriptions of acidity fail to adequately represent the acid-base chemistry in these particles because they are so small.  This project seeks to understand the limits of the applicability of an acidity measurements (here, acid dissociation constants (pKa)) in describing the behavior of acids and bases in sub-100 nanometer particles. As part of a long-standing summer internship program for undergraduates, the researchers give real-time demonstrations using the AVOGADRO program, which provides an easy-to-use graphical user-interface to create acid-base molecular systems and perform preliminary, low-level simulations relevant to this project. As such, the project provides real-time demonstrations may have a substantial impact in increasing awareness of computationally-guided experiments in underrepresented minority populations, potentially leading to more minority students seeking careers in the environmental chemical sciences.

The goal of this research is to determine the limits of applicability for bulk-phase aqueous acid and base dissociation constants (pKa and pKb), particularly as regards acid-base chemistry in and on sub-100 nm particles. In this size range, the direct composition and indirect hygroscopicity measurements performed at the CLOUD chamber show that nanoparticles formed by sulfuric acid in the presence of excess based(amines and ammonia) are more acidic than predicted using thermodynamic models.  Further, the acidity appears to vary with particle size from ~10 nm (most acidic) to 50 nm (more neutralized). Knowledge of the acidity of sub-100 nm particles is important for understanding relatively simple acid-base chemistry, but also for accurately predicting acid-catalyzed processes on particle surfaces and in the bulk phase.  The specific objectives of this project are as follows: to use molecular modeling to predict pKa values for inorganic and organic acids and bases as a function of particle composition and size. This activity combines techniques such a computational quantum chemistry and molecular dynamics to model particles with diameters of up to 5 nm and to perform laboratory experiments to evaluate the predicted pKa values as a function of composition and size. This is done using a temperature- and humidity-controlled reaction chamber and chemical ionization mass spectrometers to determine precursor and nanoparticle composition.  The researchers will also develop and apply a parameterization applicable for multiscale modeling of relevant processes taking place in and on atmospheric aerosol particles. This latter research aim may lead to improvements in the predictive power of models. These models address the mechanisms and species responsible for the formation of new particles in the atmosphere, and the effects of atmospheric nanoparticles on human health and climate.

por.por_cntn:
New particle formation (NPF) involves the formation of stable nanoparticles in the atmosphere and their growth to sizes that can affect atmospheric processes and climate. The ability to predict NPF in models is critical to representing cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) and the effects of particles on climate. While it has been well documented that organic salts contribute to NPF, models based on bulk-phase aqueous systems have been unable to represent laboratory observations, and particularly the relative contribution of acids and bases to particle composition and growth. The central hypothesis of this project was that there are a range of particle sizes and compositions for which bulk-phase aqueous dissociation constants (pKa, pKb) are not sufficient to represent the observed acid-base chemistry. We sought to address this hypothesis through a combined measurement-model approach involving laboratory experiments, computational chemistry, and theoretical modeling. This approach uniquely enabled a mechanistic understanding and representation of acid-base chemistry in nanoparticles and cross-training opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in experimental and theoretical approaches for solving complex problems in chemistry.

Our team at UC Riverside specifically focused on the computational chemistry and theoretical modeling research objectives of the project. In the context of computational chemistry, this project resulted in the first quantum-based metadynamics simulations of dimethylamine in an aqueous environment, in which the free energy profile of proton transfer in the bulk and at the air-water interface was investigated. It was found that proton transfer to dimethylamine had a lower energy barrier at the surface than in the bulk, with estimated pKb values from 1.88-2.84 in bulk to 0.74-1.72 at the interface. While the absolute values should not be directly compared with experimentally-derived bulk values, the trends may be applicable to nanoparticles. In the context of theoretical modeling, our collaborators at UC Irvine showed that the measured acid:base ratio, relative to the predicted acid:base ratio based on bulk-aqueous pKa and pKb values, increases exponentially as particle size decreases. We hypothesized that the deviation as a function of particle size was due to the greater surface area at smaller sizes. Further, as particle volume decreases, the number of water molecules in the particle also decreases. There is a point at which the concept of an aqueous phase with solvated ions breaks down. We developed a system-specific model in which the deviations in measured acid:base ratio to predicted acid:base ratio as a function of particle size were represented using an exponential fit. This allowed us to modify pKa-based predictions of composition as a function of particle size in a given system. In other words, for a given system, we developed a parameterization to predict the acid:base ratio as a function of particle size. However, each system had different parameters, thus the model is not generalizable. Nonetheless, it allowed us to develop a normalized scale (i.e., the fitting parameters, or the extent of deviation at a given particle size) and a consistent framework to evaluate the deviations from equilibrium assumptions in different systems and under different experimental conditions (including observed particle size).

Over the project duration, one PhD student, one MS student, one undergraduate student, and two postdoctoral researchers contributed to this project and received training and mentorship to support their professional development. The undergraduate student expanded and completed a MATLAB-based model to predict equilibrium composition in acid-base systems. The model was used to support undergraduate students in an Applied Numerical Methods course taught at UC Riverside. In addition, lessons inspired by this project on acid-base chemistry, modeling timescales, and CCN were developed for an upper-division Fate and Transport course also taught at UCR. This project resulted in four peer-reviewed collaborative publications and most recently, a platform presentation and the annual meeting of the American Association for Aerosol Research. The combination of theoretical, computational, and observational efforts was a critical strength of this project. Analysis using only one of these tools would have given only a partial picture/perspective of these systems. When we explain our observations from a mechanistic perspective it leads to breakthroughs in fundamental understanding and model representation of organic salt formation across scales. These explanations and breakthroughs will continue through collaborations seeded during this project, as we are still pursuing a global description of the observations linked to fundamental physicochemical properties that differentiate systems.
